body:
FullCLR windows host doesn't read keys when run in separate window.
Fix: don't use Start-Process -Wait $false -NoNewWindow $false

Instead, ommit this parameters. Seems like a bug in Start-Process.
title: Fix for #491: make powershell.exe work in new window

body: Latest dotnet-nightly packages have not required this.
title: Remove temporary dotnet-publish workaround

body:
## Repro

Follow instructions to run AppVeyor build

```
Start-DevPSGithub -binDir 'C:\Users\sevoroby\Downloads\powershell-linux.FullCLR (8)'
```
### Expected

Window opened, can type in it.
### Actual

Window opened, cannot type anything in it.
### Workaround

`-NoNewWindow` works fine

```
Start-DevPSGithub -binDir 'C:\Users\sevoroby\Downloads\powershell-linux.FullCLR (8)' -NoNewWindow
```
## Environment

Verified on a68aa450cca203d7b0306e5979d120d9d89e1cbd Windows Client 10.0.10586.63

labels.name: Issue-Bug

body:
## Repro

``` powershell
function prompt() {get-foo}
```
### Expected

custom prompt throws error, so we are using default prompt. 
Not sure what's Full PS behavior (not a crash for sure), please double-check.
### Actual

process crashes and prints exception stack:

```
Unhandled Exception: System.Management.Automation.CommandNotFoundException: The term 'get-foo' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program. Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
   at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PipelineBase.Invoke(IEnumerable input)
   at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.Pipeline.Invoke()
   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host.Listener.Prompt(Runspace rs)
   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host.Listener.Run()
   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host.Program.Main(String[] args)
Aborted (core dumped)
```
## Environment

Tested on 6d5194057ea55eccac00ef6566d9edc9b8862fc4 Ubuntu 14.04

body:
After using the "less" command, up, down, left, right, home, and end return alphabetically characters into the buffer instead of being read as special keys.

Guessing whatever is calling into "less" is setting some sort of character encoding that is not being set back, and then the caret or escape characters are being interpreted incorrectly. 

"A" is being mapped to Up, "B" to down, "C" to left, "D" to right, "H" to home and "E" to end.

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

The [schema](http://json.schemastore.org/project) supports it, but I don't believe it's enabled yet.

This issue is twofold: we need to be able to verify assembly strong names (aka tokens) within PowerShell itself; we also need to generate signed DLLs.

body:
Per this [issue](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/1019) the behavior of `dotnet publish --output bin` is about to change on us (it already has on Windows).

We'll need to fix our scripts, Travis, and documentation to account for this, but ideally the change is rolled back. I really prefer having `./bin/powershell` as the output.

title: Remove workaround of previous dotnet-publish behavior

body:
## Update mapped compileFiles

Removed `CorePsPlatform.cs` from the build mapping so that I could perform
it before merging.

Note that SMA by default now builds with a bunch of tracing files for
ETW, which cannot be compiled on Linux and must be hand-removed from the
windows-build auto-generated compileFiles output.
## Add packages required for updated sources

Commands.Utility now needs Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CSharp, which doesn't
explicitly target `dnxcore50`, so now Commands.Utility and the packages
which depend on it now much `import` the Portable Windows framework.
This also required adding the aspnetvnext feed.

System.Management.Automation now requires System.Diagnostics.StackTrace.
## Bump monad and windows-build submodules

See [monad PR](https://github.com/PowerShell/psl-monad/pull/7) and [windows-build PR](https://github.com/PowerShell/psl-windows-build/pull/2).

title: Enable Travis CI

body:
Requires #19 so that `Invoke-Pester -EnableExit` can be used for test failure threshold comparison.

Will fail if project fails to build or more than 14 Pester tests fail (these are under investigation).

Will not currently fail if native tests fail because we will likely have a separate job for that.
title: Enable Travis CI

- Use language 'cpp' because 'csharp' would bring in Mono
- Set to Trusty Tahr (Ubuntu 14.04)
- Install dotnet-cli

body: This PR implemented the functionality that we needed  https   github.com dotnet corefx pull 4639  However, the API has not yet been exposed in the libraries reference assembly, hence our current need to patch it.  We're simply waiting on this https   github.com dotnet corefx issues 4636 so we can update our packages and remove the patch.  Necessary APIs exposed by .NET team, patch removed.  VSO create date - 12/18/2015 16:08:00     VSO closed date - 1/12/2016 13:34:00
